ResponseText: Roughly 24 states in the U.S.predominantly westernhave a system of initiative or referendum amendments on their books which allow voters to vote on a variety of issues in a straight up or down matter, often during general elections. These have become wildly popular of late, it seems to me anyway, and it is difficult to find any criticism of the practice in the media. I would like to offer some here. Of course, it is our right to have this power, and it is enumerated in many of our states Constitutions. My contention is that were exercising it too vigorously. I have been guided by a simple principle in government: If a thing is good for the stability of the government, Im for it. If it tends to disrupt the stability Im against it. You could say Im a Big-Stability-in-Government guy. Initiatives and Referenda (IR) tend to disrupt stability in a huge way, IMO. We are a Constitutional Republic, not a democracy, and I believe we should act accordingly. We elect our representatives to vote in our interests, and it is this removal and critical distance from the clash and spark of politics which has allowed us to outfit a strong keel on our ship of state. Some people, maddened by slow or non-existent progress attempt to take matters into their own hands and so submit an idea for an IR, garnering signatures on petitions in an always populist fashion, doing an end-run around our politicians. In this way, modern America is beginning to resemble Athenian democracy, sheer mob rule. I think its a sorry turn of events. I would like to hear what you think.

I used to live in San Francisco. Both SF and Claifornia have initiative procedures. It works, poorly. Many laws get approved by the people, and then the state is forced, by law, to spend millions fighting the law in court because it's unconstitutional. Other times, stupid laws get passed. One such law states that property taxes will only be reassesed when some buys property. As long as you hold onto your place, your property taxes won't go up. However, schools are funded largely by property taxes. School expences went up with inflation, property taxes didn't, and the California public school system went from being one of the best in the country to one of the worst. Law isn't easy. Writing good law is something that takes skill, knowledge, and practice. That's what we hire politicians to do. Asking "the people" if a law is good or not makes about as much sense as polling your neighbors as to what open heart procedure you should get. We should let politicians do their jobs, and if we don't like what they do we should vote them out. Trying to get average people to decide if a given piece of legislature is a good law or not simply doesn't work most of the time. We're not politicians, we're not lawyers, we simply don't have the knowledge or experience to decide.

ResponseText: Referenda exhibit a form of direct democracy only in which, it can be argued, is the sovereign power of the people exercised effectively. In a representative democracy, the electorate has little power to influence politics except that provided by an election. This influence quickly wanes and the representative often behaves like a "free agent" unwilling , or unable, to make good on promises that were made to the electorate. Political frustration can build up which a referendum might usefully release. Generally, the indirect system of representation permits the emergence of "experts" at key positions in government - who may be answerable to the people but who are not merely puppets of the people. Usually, the superiority of this system of government may be allowed; but the possibility of the people "speaking directly" through a referendum is a useful check on those governments who through insouciance and hubris turn a deaf ear to the pressing concerns of the people.

Given the opportunity to cast a ballot in the matter, as they had in several states during our last election, it is not surprising the idea crashed and burned. ResponseText: I think your objections to the promiscuous use of referenda are intelligent and well argued. In general, perhaps only in consitutional issues or matters of great national consequence, should the "sovereign will" of the people be directly consulted by a referendum. Elections of representatives are perfectly adequate for almost every other political contingency. However, the United States is a special case. It's a continental union of 50 (?) states with a lot of power devolved or delegated from the center. It's a long way, for example, from Alaska to Washington DC, and the federal government is probably seen as remote and out of touch with the "pressing concerns of the people". You might be able to influence a policy determined in St Paul, Minnesota, but you could make no difference to the "Washington view", no matter how much noise you make. To many, perhaps most people, the state is a more meaningful political abstraction than the concept of a far away federal government. For these sorts of reasons, the use of referenda has been conceived, I think, as a way of "connecting people to politics" - i.e. to the state administration. Once you submit complicated questions/propositions to the people, you're going to get slick populist answers. They won't be answers that educated and liberal minds will be thrilled by; but it's difficult to argue the elitist theory that "experts" and the intelligentsia know best etc. However, I agree with you, civil rights among many progressive measures would never have been passed into law if the opinions of the masses had been directly consulted by a popular vote issue by issue.

Basically, while the concerns raised are valid, it's a matter that's up to the state. We're a federal republic, and under the federal system, certain areas of governance (fewer and fewer these days, it seems) are left in the hands of the state and local governments.

ResponseText: Thanks for your generous comments: the Campaign for Direct Democracy has had zero impact here. A referendum is granted only in the most exceptional circumstances (usually of consitutional importance) and Parliamentary democracy is considered so sufficiently "close" to people's concerns that referenda are supposed to be largely redundant expedients. That referenda are implemented for frivolous purposes and significant issues are trivialised in order to court the popular vote, worries the thoughtful person. But this is a price you must pay in the US for having "democracy in depth". I think some "elitism" is inescapable - even in the most democratic society imaginable. It's simply a fact of life that some opinions are better informed than others, some people are better educated than others, etc. Though your presentation of the downside to a popular practice might open you up to an accusation of elitism, why should you censor yourself on issues that you have carefully considered ? You may be in a minority, but intelligent enquiry has never been an activity that appeals to the majority.
